data.title: Nice Baby and the Angel
data.text:
1973 studio album by David Blue

Nice Baby and the AngelStudio album by Released1973GenreSinger-songwriter, country rockLength35:00LabelAsylum

Nice Baby and the Angel is a 1973 album by American singer-songwriter David Blue. It was released by Asylum Records and produced by Graham Nash. The album was Blue's second release on Asylum Records.

History

[edit]

Nice Baby and the Angel was recorded in collaboration with Dave Mason, David Lindley, and Glenn Frey.[1] The album features backing vocals from Nash and Jennifer Warnes on the track "Lady O' Lady". The album is a departure from Blue's folk style with more country, singer-songwriter oriented tracks.

The album was released in mid-1973, to a lukewarm response. It did not chart, nor did either of the singles released: "True to You/Dancing Girl", and "Outlaw Man/Troubadour Song". "Outlaw Man" was picked up by Glenn Frey, who introduced it to the Eagles, who included it on their second album, Desperado.

Track listing

[edit]

Reception

[edit]

Professional ratingsReview scoresSourceRatingAllMusicRobert ChristgauC-

Initial reception of Nice Baby and the Angel was mixed. In late April 1973, Billboard praised Blue as a "veteran singer-songwriter," and selected "Outlaw Man", the title track, and "Dancing Girl", as the best cuts on the album.[2] Robert Christgau was more critical, giving the album a C- and calling it "outtakes from the Eagles."[3]

In a retrospective review for AllMusic, William Ruhlmann commented on Nash and Lindley's contributions to the album positively, while noting that Blue's lyrical content was starting to wane.[1]

Aftermath

[edit]

Nice Baby and the Angel failed to chart. Blue released two further albums, both on Asylum. Com'n Back For More was released in 1975. Bob Dylan, Don Felder, Joni Mitchell, and members from the band America contributed to the album, even though it was a commercial and critical failure.[citation needed]
